# Home Automation
Home automation is made of 12 different repositories:

#### Raspberry Pi Clients
* [Alarm Siren Raspberry Pi Client](https://github.com/OronNadiv/alarm-siren-raspberry-client) - raspberry-pi client for the alarm's siren.
* [Camera Raspberry Pi Client](https://github.com/OronNadiv/camera-raspberry-client) - raspberry-pi client for the camera.
* [Garage Door Raspberry Pi Client](https://github.com/OronNadiv/garage-door-raspberry-client) - raspberry-pi client for the garage door.
* [Motion Sensor Raspberry Pi Client](https://github.com/OronNadiv/motion-sensor-raspberry-client) - raspberry-pi client for the alarm's motion sensor.

#### Servers
* [Alarm System API](https://github.com/OronNadiv/alarm-system-api) - TODO: describe

## Installation Instructions for the Server Micro-Services

Prerequisites:
* [Create Heroku account][heroku].
* Download and install [Heroku toolbelt][toolbelt].
* [Node JS][node-js] 6.x (or higher).
* [OpenSSL][openssl] v1.0.2 (or higher)
* [PostgreSQL DB][postgres]
* [Redis Cloud][redis]
* [Papertrail][papertrail]
* [Mailgun][mailgun] (optional)

* Step 1: Clone the server's repository to your local machine.
```
git clone <repository git url>
```
* Step 2: Create a new Heroku app.
```
cd <cloned repository root directory>
heroku apps:create <app name>
```
* Step 3: Push the cloned repository to the newly created Heroku app.
```
git push heroku master
```
* Step 4: Each server app requires a set of environment variables in order to run.  Set the required environment variables using the following command:
```
heroku config:set <KEY>=<VALUE>
```
* Step 5: Scale the web dyno by running the following command:
```
heroku ps:scale web=1 -a <app name> 
```


## Installation Instructions for the Raspberry Pi Clients
* Step 1: Install [Raspbian](https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/raspbian/)
* Step 2: SSH to the raspberry pi 
 `ssh pi@<IP address>`
 Default user name: `pi`.
 Default password: `raspberry`.  It is a good idea to change the default password.
* Step 3: Install NVM
```
cd ~
curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/v0.31.0/install.sh | bash
source ~/.profile
nvm install 6.3.0
```
Node JS v6.3.0 is the latest version that ran successfully on Raspbian.
 
* Step 4: Install quick2wire-gpio-admin:
```
git clone https://github.com/sli/quick2wire-gpio-admin.git
cd quick2wire-gpio-admin
make
sudo make install
sudo adduser $USER gpio
sudo reboot
```

* Step 5: Install execution script - Each raspberry pi client repository contain an execution script in the `/scripts` directory.  Copy the script to the user's root directory and fill the missing parameters.
* Step 6: Supervisor
  a. [Download and Install supervisor](http://supervisord.org/installing.html)
  b. copy the configuration file from the `/scripts` directory to `/etc/supervisor/conf.d/`

## Generating private and public keys
Both the servers and clients require public and private keys in order to uniquely identify them.  
Here are the instructions to create them:
```
openssl genrsa -out private_key.pem 2048
openssl rsa -in private_key.pem -pubout -out public_key.pem
```
